td.content: LIPID PANEL WITH REFLEX TO DIRECT LDL (14852)
td.footnote:
Reviewed date:08/13/2025 10:39:05 AM
Interpretation:
Performing Lab:Z99, Quest Diagnostics-Clifton 1 Insights Drive, Clifton NJ 07012-2355 Peter E Fisher
Notes/Report:
NON-FASTING
NON-FASTING NON-FASTING NON-FASTING

td.paragraph: Reference range: <100
Desirable range <100 mg/dL for primary prevention;
<70 mg/dL for patients with CHD or diabetic patients
with > or = 2 CHD risk factors.
LDL-C is now calculated using the Martin-Hopkins
calculation, which is a validated novel method providing
better accuracy than the Friedewald equation in the
estimation of LDL-C.
Martin SS et al. JAMA. 2013;310(19): 2061-2068
(http://education.QuestDiagnostics.com/faq/FAQ164)
For patients with diabetes plus 1 major ASCVD risk
factor, treating to a non-HDL-C goal of <100 mg/dL
(LDL-C of <70 mg/dL) is considered a therapeutic
option.

td.paragraph: For the purpose of screening for the presence of
diabetes:
<5.7% Consistent with the absence of diabetes
5.7-6.4% Consistent with increased risk for diabetes
(prediabetes)
> or =6.5% Consistent with diabetes
This assay result is consistent with a decreased risk
of diabetes.
Currently, no consensus exists regarding use of
hemoglobin A1c for diagnosis of diabetes in children.
According to American Diabetes Association (ADA)
guidelines, hemoglobin A1c <7.0% represents optimal
control in non-pregnant diabetic patients. Different
metrics may apply to specific patient populations.
Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes(ADA).

We did an echocardiogram on him, which showed preserved ejection fraction, RV dilatation likely suggestive of sleep apnea. We are going to arrange for a sleep study for him. He had a carotid Doppler done which shows mild atherosclerotic plaque in his carotid arteries without any significant internal carotid artery stenosis. During his next visit, we will arrange for a venous reflux study. Compression stockings and leg elevation advised. We advised him to refill his losartan and HCTZ. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle modifications were encouraged and endorsed. We discussed the importance of a healthy lifestyle with weight reduction. All questions and concerns answered and addressed. Patient agrees with the plan of care. Follow up in 1 week or sooner if symptoms arise.
Scribed by Devender Bisht under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj

We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent echo and carotid doppler with results noted above. His blood pressure is mildly elevated today. If it is persistently high, we will consider addition of amlodipine to his anti-hypertensive treatment therapy. For his leg ache, leg heaviness, and leg discomfort with associated leg swelling, we will arrange for an ABI/PVR today. ABI/PVR reviewed and discussed revealing RLE 1.18 and LLE 0.99. For borderline ABI, we will also arrange for bilateral lower extremity arterial doppler today. We will also arrange for a bilateral lower extremity venous reflux study for ache, heaviness, fatigue, and swelling in his legs. He was encouraged to maintain compliant with compression socks during the day, rest and elevate his legs at night. Educational material on venous insufficiency and venous ablation therapy was provided to the patient. We will see him back in one week or sooner if symptoms arise. We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent labs. His liver enzymes are mildly elevated as is his LDL. He would like to try diet modifications before pharmacological treatment therapy for his hyperlipidemia. He was strongly encouraged to maintain a heart healthy and low-fat diet. We will see him back in one week.
Scribed by Mohd. Irshad under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP.

We reviewed and discussed results of his recent testing with results noted above. For his persistent ache, heaviness, fatigue, and leg swelling despite conservative treatment with compression sock therapy, plan will be to arrange for an LGSV ablation today. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in great detail. All questions and concerns were answered and addressed. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle encouraged and endorsed. His blood pressure is elevated again today. We will start him on amlodipine 5 mg every day in addition to his losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. Side effects of the medications were discussed. We will reevaluate his blood pressure at the next visit. We will see him back in one week or sooner if symptoms arise. She agrees with the plan of care.We discussed weight management and importance of weight reduction for improvement in his CV risk. He previously was sent Zepbound, however, his insurance was requesting more information from us at the time, which we will send and arrange and try to get him Zepbound again. If not, we discussed Semaglutide injections in the office, which he would like to consider. We will see him back in one week's time or sooner if symptoms arise.
Scribed by Mohd. Irshad under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP.

td.paragraph: His
blood pressure remains elevated today. We will increase his amlodipine to 10 mg
daily. Side effects of the medications were discussed. For persistent ache,
heaviness, and fatigue despite conservative treatment with compression therapy,
we will arrange for RGSV ablation today. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were
discussed in great detail. He was encouraged to remain compliant with
compression stocking therapy during the day, rest and elevate his legs at
night. Semaglutide was administered to his left arm without complications 0.25
mg SC today. Side-effects of the medication was discussed. Risks, benefits, and
alternatives discussed. He understands that long term side effects are not well
known. He denies any history of medullary thyroid cancer or endocrine neoplasia
syndrome. Educational material was provided to him. He was encouraged to
maintain a caloric deficit for optimal weight reduction. He was also encouraged
to increase his activity and also his hydration as well. He will return in 1
week. We will reevaluate his blood pressure at that time.
Scribed
by Intekhab Alam under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP.

tr.td: His blood pressure is stable today, however, for his increased leg swelling, we will discontinue his amlodipine today. We will start him on hydralazine 25 mg 3 times a day. Side effects of the medications were discussed in great detail. For his persistent ache, heaviness and fatigue in the leg despite conservative treatment with compression stocking therapy, we will arrange for LSSV ablation today. Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in great detail. He is tolerating Semaglutide well. Semaglutide 0.25 mg administered SC to the right arm today without complication. He understands the long-term side effects of Semaglutide are not well known. He was encouraged to maintain diet modifications and caloric deficit for optimal weight reduction. We will see him back in one week or sooner if symptoms arise. He also reports completing recent sleep study for which results are pending at this time.
Scribed by Mohd Irshad under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP

We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent sleep study with results noted above. We will arrange for an auto-CPAP. All questions and concerns were answered and addressed. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle encouraged and endorsed. We will see him back in 2-3 weeks or sooner if symptoms arise. He agrees to the plan of care.
Scribed by Intekhab Alam under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP

td.paragraph: Left
lower extremity ablation site is healing well without evidence of bleeding,
drainage, or hematoma. We will arrange for a left lower extremity venous
doppler for post-ablation evaluation today. Preliminary images reviewed and
discussed without evidence for DVT. He is tolerating Semaglutide well and will
continue. Semaglutide 0.25 mg administered SC to the left arm without
complication today. He understands that long-term side effects of Semaglutide
are not well known. He was encouraged to maintain a caloric deficit for optimal
weight reduction, decrease his intake of fried fatty foods, and increase his
hydration and his activity levels. He was recently started on hydralazine 25 mg
t.i.d. and is tolerating well. His blood pressure is stable today. We will see
him back in 1 week or sooner if symptoms arise. If persistent symptoms in his
legs despite conservative treatment therapy with compression stockings, we will
arrange for an RSSV ablation at that time. We reviewed and discussed the
results of his recent sleep study which revealed severe obstructive sleep
apnea. He is pending initiation of a CPAP at this time. He was encouraged to
maintain compliance. He agrees to the plan of care

tr.td: Scribed by Mohd. Irshad under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP.

td.paragraph: His weight is unchanged this week. We
will increase his dose of Semaglutide as he is tolerating wells. Semaglutide
0.5 mg administered SC to the right arm without complication today. He was
encouraged to maintain a diet high in protein and low carb and reduce his
intake of fried fatty foods. His blood pressure is stable today. He understands
that long-term side effects of Semaglutide are not well known. He understands
the importance of caloric deficit for optimal weight reduction. He was recently
diagnosed with sleep apnea and is still pending a CPAP at this time. For his
leg ache and heaviness despite conservative treatment with compression stocking
therapy, plan will be to arrange for an RSSV ablation today. Risks, benefits
and alternatives were discussed great detail. All questions and concerns were
answered and addressed. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle encouraged and
endorsed.
The patient was
monitored for over 15 minutes post procedure. The patient was evaluated for any
adverse or allergic reaction. Vital signs remained stable. No indication of any
adverse reaction to the site or to any allergic reaction. Blood pressure
remained stable

tr.td: Scribed by Mohd. Irshad under the supervision of Dr. Rishi Bajaj and Marion Hayes, FNP.

He is tolerating Semaglutide well and will continue Semaglutide 0.5 mg administered SC to the left arm without complications. He understands that long-term side effects of Semaglutide are not well known. He was encouraged to maintain a caloric deficit for optimal weight reduction, increase his hydration and also his activity level. For post ablation evaluation, we will arrange for bilateral lower extremity venous doppler today. Preliminary images reviewed and discussed without evidence for DVT. We will see him back in 1 week or sooner if symptoms arise. He was encouraged to maintain compliance with compression stocking therapy during the day, rest and elevate his legs at night.

td.paragraph: The
patient was monitored for over 15 minutes post procedure. The patient was
evaluated for any adverse or allergic reaction. Vital signs remained stable. No
indication of any adverse reaction to the site or to any allergic reaction.
Blood pressure remained stable.

This is a 37-year-old male with significant medical history of morbid obesity, hypertension, edema, and venous insufficiency who presents today for CV follow-up with complaints of leg discomfort and leg swelling. He reports leg ache and heaviness with associated leg swelling. He also reports discomfort more so to the left lower extremity. He does have pain and discomfort when he walks. He is significantly overweight and has a very poor diet. He is inquiring about weight loss medication today as well. He denies any chest pain. He complains of shortness of breath on exertion. Denies any shortness of breath at rest, syncope, or near syncopal events.
Echocardiogram: Preserved LVEF, RV dilatation
Carotid doppler: Mild atherosclerotic plaque, no significant ICA stenosis
ABI/PVR: RLE 1.18 and LLE 0.99

We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent echo and carotid doppler with results noted above. His blood pressure is mildly elevated today. If it is persistently high, we will consider addition of amlodipine to his anti-hypertensive treatment therapy. For his leg ache, leg heaviness, and leg discomfort with associated leg swelling, we will arrange for an ABI/PVR today. ABI/PVR reviewed and discussed revealing RLE 1.18 and LLE 0.99. For borderline ABI, we will also arrange for bilateral lower extremity arterial doppler today. We will also arrange for a bilateral lower extremity venous reflux study for ache, heaviness, fatigue, and swelling in his legs. He was encouraged to maintain compliant with compression socks during the day, rest and elevate his legs at night. Educational material on venous insufficiency and venous ablation therapy was provided to the patient. We will see him back in one week or sooner if symptoms arise. We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent labs. His liver enzymes are mildly elevated as is his LDL. He would like to try diet modifications before pharmacological treatment therapy for his hyperlipidemia. He was strongly encouraged to maintain a heart healthy and low-fat diet. We will see him back in one week.

This is a 37-year-old male with significant medical history of morbid obesity, hypertension, and venous insufficiency, who presents today for CV follow-up for results of recent sleep study and with complaints of leg discomfort. He is also here for weight management. He reports some mild tenderness to the left lower extremity ablation site. He reports tolerating Semaglutide well and has felt a decrease in his appetite since his last visit with us. He also recently underwent a sleep study for which he is here for results. He denies any chest pain, chest pressure, shortness of breath at rest, syncope, or near-syncopal events. He does complain of shortness of breath with exertion, unchanged from his prior complaint.
Echocardiogram: Preserved LVEF, RV dilatation
Carotid doppler: Mild atherosclerotic plaque, no significant ICA stenosis
ABI/PVR: RLE 1.18 and LLE 0.99
Bilateral lower extremity arterial doppler: No evidence of significant stenosis in bilateral lower extremity arteries, mild plaque seen.
Venous reflux study bilateral lower extremities: No evidence of DVT, however, significant bilateral GSV reflux noted.
LGSV ablation 04/18/2024
RGSV ablation 04/25/2024
Current weight: 430 lbs
LSSV ablation on 05/08/24

Left lower extremity ablation site is healing well without evidence of bleeding, drainage, or hematoma. We will arrange for a left lower extremity venous doppler for post-ablation evaluation today. Preliminary images reviewed and discussed without evidence for DVT. He is tolerating Semaglutide well and will continue. Semaglutide 0.25 mg administered SC to the left arm without complication today. He understands that long-term side effects of Semaglutide are not well known. He was encouraged to maintain a caloric deficit for optimal weight reduction, decrease his intake of fried fatty foods, and increase his hydration and his activity levels. He was recently started on hydralazine 25 mg t.i.d. and is tolerating well. His blood pressure is stable today. We will see him back in 1 week or sooner if symptoms arise. If persistent symptoms in his legs despite conservative treatment therapy with compression stockings, we will arrange for an RSSV ablation at that time. We reviewed and discussed the results of his recent sleep study which revealed severe obstructive sleep apnea. He is pending initiation of a CPAP at this time. He was encouraged to maintain compliance. He agrees to the plan of care.

This is a 37-year-old male with significant medical history of morbid obesity, hypertension, and venous insufficiency, who presents today for weight management and with complaints of leg discomfort and associated leg swelling. He reports compliance with compression therapy during the day, resting and elevating his legs at night. He reports improvement in his leg ache and heaviness since completion of prior ablations; however, he reports ongoing leg swelling. He reports tolerating Semaglutide well and does report noticing a decrease to his appetite. He denies any chest pain, chest pressure, shortness of breath at rest, syncope or near-syncopal events. Patient was informed of the telemedicine visit by our office staff. Telemedicine was described in detail to the patient as the use of synchronous video and audio communication to provide clinical care from a distance. A telemedicine visit can provide the same medical standard of care for specific conditions. The patient was informed that the practice staff located at the provider's office would assist in carrying out any recommendations and clinical care.
Patient Location: Home
Lack of strict HIPPA Rules. Patient expressed verbal interest in the telemedicine visit and granted consent to proceed.

This is a 37-year-old male with a significant medical history of morbid obesity, hypertension, edema, and venous insufficiency who presents today for an initial CV consult with complaints of his lower extremity lymphedema and venous insufficiency along with stasis dermatitis and skin changes, and heaviness and achiness in his lower extremities with leg swelling. He denies any history of smoking. Denies chest pain, chest pressure, palpitations, dizziness, SOB, blurred or double vision, syncope or near syncopal events. Denies any family history of premature coronary artery disease or sudden cardiac death.

Echo: Normal LV size and function. EF 55% No significant aortic valve stenosis. Moderate aortic sclerosis. Mild LVH. Trace aortic regurgitation. Mild tricuspid regurgitation. Mild mitral regurgitation. No significant pericardial effusion. Mild pulmonary hypertension. PASP 28 mm Hg.
Venous doppler: Significant reflux present in bilateral GSVs

We did an echocardiogram on him, which showed preserved ejection fraction, RV dilatation likely suggestive of sleep apnea. We are going to arrange for a sleep study for him. He had a carotid Doppler done which shows mild atherosclerotic plaque in his carotid arteries without any significant internal carotid artery stenosis. During his next visit, we will arrange for a venous reflux study. Compression stockings and leg elevation advised. We advised him to refill his losartan and HCTZ. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle modifications were encouraged and endorsed. We discussed the importance of a healthy lifestyle with weight reduction. All questions and concerns answered and addressed. Patient agrees with the plan of care. Follow up in 1 week or sooner if symptoms arise.
